p: The leaf extract of B. ciliata possesses antimalarial property [ 43]. Its leaves are revered to as “Pashanabheda”, which designates the litholytic property [ 44]. In Nepal, 1:1 mixture (one teaspoon) of the dried B. ciliata rhizome-juice and honey is administered to post-partum women 2–3 times a day as a tonic and remedy for digestive disorders (carminative) [ 38]. The rhizome-decoction may also be consumed orally as antipyretic and antihelmintic [ 45].
